awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Tephrochronology of a South Pole Ice Core
awd_abstract_narration:
Dunbar/1543454

Antarctic ice cores offer unparalleled records of earth?s climate back to almost one million years and perhaps beyond. Layers of volcanic ash (tephra) embedded in glacial ice can be used to establish an accurate ice core chronology. In order to use a visible or ultrafine volcanic ash layer as a time-stratigraphic marker, a unique geochemical fingerprint must be established, and this forms the basis of our research. This award will investigate the volcanic record in the 1751 m ice core that was completed at the South Pole during the 2015/16 field season. The core is in an ideal location to link the existing, established, volcanic records in East and West Antarctica, and therefore to connect and integrate those records, allowing the climate records of ice cores to be directly compared, as well as to focus research on the most widespread and significant volcanic eruptions from West Antarctica.  Tephra derived from well-dated, large, tropical volcanic eruptions that may have had an impact on climate will also be studied.   Recent success in identifying and analyzing very fine ash particles from these types of eruptions makes it likely that we will be able to pinpoint some of these eruptions, which will allow the sulfate peaks associated with these layers to be positively identified and dated. Volcanic forcing time series developed from earlier South Pole ice cores based on preserved sulfate were crucial for testing climate models, but without tephra analysis, the origin of these layers remains uncertain. 

Work on the tephra layers in the South Pole ice core has a number of significant specific objectives, some with practical applications to the basic science goals of Antarctic ice coring, and others that represent independent scientific contributions in their own right. These include: (1) providing independently dated time-intervals in the core, particularly for the deepest ice, (2) quantitatively linking tephra records across Antarctica with the goal of allowing direct and robust climate comparisons between these different parts of the continent, (3) providing information for large local eruptions, that will lead to direct estimates of eruption magnitude and dispersal patterns of Antarctic volcanoes, several of which will likely erupt again. The initial stages of the work will be carried out by identifying silicate-bearing horizons in the ice core, using several methods.  Once found, silicate particles will be imaged so that morphological characteristics of the particles can be used to identify volcanic origin.  Particles identified as tephra will then be chemically analyzed using electron microprobe and laser ablation ICP-MS.  Samples that yield a robust chemical fingerprint will be statistically correlated to known eruptions, and this will be used to address the goals described above.  Broader impacts of this project fall into the areas of education of future generation of researchers, outreach and international cooperation. These activities will continue to promote forward progress in integrating the Antarctic tephra record and more broadly tying it to the global volcanic record.

por.por_cntn:
During large explosive volcanic eruptions, sulfate and ultra fine particles are injected up to 50 km into the atmosphere. The residence time of these small volcanogenic particles or cryptotephra in the atmosphere is relatively short and ranges from weeks to several months. Surprisingly, in some cases, cryptotephra can be found thousands of kilometers from the source volcano. The primary focus of this collaborative project is to explore the applications and limitations of ice core cryptotephra deposits  using novel and tested sample preparation and analytical methodologies. The major goal was to carefully document how cryptotephra deposits identified in the ice core drilled at the South Pole (SPC-14) are affiliated with the intervals of increased sulfate.  In ice cores volcanic time series developed by previous studies, large sulfate peaks are attributed to past known tropical volcanic events, mainly based on the eruption timing, duration and magnitude of the signal. The correct identification, precise dating and attribution of sulfate from explosive volcanic eruptions in polar ice cores is important for investigating volcanic influence on climate, for constraining ice core timescales and for reconstruction of volcanic eruption parameters.

Geochemical compositions of cryptotephra provide unique means to confirm established correlations of sulfate spikes to source volcanos and help to reconstruct past atmospheric  transport environments.  Measurements of geochemical composition or fingerprint of ultra fine (5-15 microns in size) cryptotephra particles is extremely challenging. During the last decade, the UMaine team improved methodology for extraction and geochemical parametrization of ultra fine cryptotephra using electron microbeam instrumentation. Applying this new methodology, 158 intervals of large sulfate anomalies attributed to tropical volcanic eruptions were investigated in the SPC-14 ice core.  Each interval was subsampled for several subannual subsections and samples with mounted in epoxy resin particles were examined on the UMaine Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) instrument for the presence of  cryptotephra particles.  Identified first based on only visual characteristics, individual cryptotephra ﻿particles were further  investigated to obtain their geochemical composition using the Energy Dispersive Spectrometry (EDS) system integrated with the UMaine SEM.  Geochemical fingerprints of identified volcanic glass particles were compared with the geochemistry of tephra that erupted from potential source volcanoes using various tephra databases and publications.

About a dozen single cryptotephra particles compositionally distinct from Antarctic sources have been characterized in the SPC-14 ice core, but a possible source volcanic eruption was established for only a few cryptotephra-rich deposits. These deposits were correlated with the 1257 C.E. eruption of Samalas volcano in Indonesia, and Reclus eruption in South America. The majority of Antarctic ice cores capture increased volcanic sulfate concentrations in the 1880s CE. A large number of cryptotephra particles were found in the SPC-14 ice core in the interval of increased sulfate attributed to the 1883 C.E. Krakatau volcano eruption in Indonesia. The geochemical signature of these particles are similar to both highly evolved magmas from the Krakatau 1883 C.E. eruption and with a unique phase of the 1886 CE Tarawera eruption of Okataina Volcanic Center, New Zealand. 

These findings confirm the complexity of identification and precise dating of explosive volcanic eruptions in ice core records. Together with our collaborators Dunbar and Iverson, we determined that the developed SPC-14 tephra record is very diverse in origin. The majority of visible tephra layers have Antarctic sources and together with unique cryptotephra deposits from non-Antarctic sources contribute to the development of an Antarctic tephrochonological framework that provides unique insight on past volcanism, atmospheric circulation patterns and interaction with the climate system.

This project?s educational and broader impact components included training a new generation of scientists in interdisciplinary collaborative research skills. This project supported research of two graduate students at UMaine and a number of undergraduate students gained experience working in the laboratories and on the instrumentation. Project activities contributed to international cooperation required to work on globally dispersed tephra deposits. Published methods, results and open research data will foster future research on improving parameterization of volcanic products in ice cores and for integrating Antarctic tephrochronology within the global tephrochronological framework.
